articles.headline: Yeah, They Torture Jeans. But It’s All for the Sake of Fashion.
articles.snippet: Sales of jeans with the beat-up look are booming on both sides of the Atlantic, making battered jeans a case study of global competition.
articles.abstract: Sales of jeans with the beat-up look are booming on both sides of the Atlantic, making battered jeans a case study of global competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: VEDELAGO, Italy — Giovanni Petrin remembers well his first efforts at beating up jeans.

articles.headline: Wave of Violence in Baghdad Puts 3-Day Death Toll Past 100
articles.snippet: Many Iraqis say the worsening security crisis in Baghdad and neighboring provinces feels like a low-grade civil war.
articles.abstract: Many Iraqis say the worsening security crisis in Baghdad and neighboring provinces feels like a low-grade civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 11 — More than 50 people were killed in Baghdad on Tuesday in violence that included a double suicide bombing near busy entrances to the fortified Green Zone, scattered shootings, mortar attacks, a series of car bombs and the ambush of a bus with Shiite mourners returning from a burial.

articles.headline: U.S. Finance Pulls Biotech Across Seas
articles.snippet: Some European biotechnology companies consider their science second to none, while conceding the superiority of American financial markets.
articles.abstract: Some European biotechnology companies consider their science second to none, while conceding the superiority of American financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Scottish economic development agency injected about $9 million into the biotechnology company Cyclacel last October, the country’s enterprise minister explained that “there could not be a more important company for Scotland’s future.”

articles.headline: Olympics Imperil Historic Beijing Neighborhood
articles.snippet: Will the 2008 Olympics enhance the city‘s ‘‘cultural heritage’’ or help finish off what remains of old Beijing?
articles.abstract: Will the 2008 Olympics enhance the city‘s ‘‘cultural heritage’’ or help finish off what remains of old Beijing?
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A short walk from Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People, a historic neighborhood named Qianmen is an eerie picture of destruction. Ancient homes lie in rubble. Scavengers squat in alleyways and wait to ransack vacated buildings.

articles.headline: Series of Bombs Explode on 7 Trains in India, Killing Scores
articles.snippet: Seven bomb blasts brought Mumbai, India’s financial capital, to a panicked standstill, resurrecting memories of past bloodbaths.
articles.abstract: Seven bomb blasts brought Mumbai, India’s financial capital, to a panicked standstill, resurrecting memories of past bloodbaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India, July 11 — A string of powerful bombs ripped through a vital spine of Mumbai’s commuter train system during the evening rush hour on Tuesday, killing nearly 200 people, bringing India’s financial capital to a standstill and resurrecting memories of bloodbaths past.
articles.byline: By Saritha Rai and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Russians and U.S. Push Hard on Trade
articles.snippet: Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization.
articles.abstract: Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 11 — Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: White House Says Terror Detainees Hold Basic Rights
articles.snippet: The White House conceded on Tuesday for the first time that terror suspects held by the United States had a right under international law to basic human and legal protections under the Geneva Conventions.      The statement reverses a position the...
articles.abstract: The White House conceded on Tuesday for the first time that terror suspects held by the United States had a right under international law to basic human and legal protections under the Geneva Conventions.      The statement reverses a position the White House had held since shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, and it represents a victory for those within the administration who argued that the United States' refusal to extend Geneva protections to Qaeda prisoners was harming the country's standing abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11 - The White House conceded on Tuesday for the first time that terror suspects held by the United States had a right under international law to basic human and legal protections under the Geneva Conventions.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Chinese Company Intends to Build MGs in Oklahoma
articles.snippet: Can the mystique of a British sports car be recreated by a Chinese company in America's heartland?     That's the bet by Nanjing Automobile Group, which plans to resurrect the fabled MG marque in a tricontinental demonstration of how truly global ...
articles.abstract: Can the mystique of a British sports car be recreated by a Chinese company in America's heartland?     That's the bet by Nanjing Automobile Group, which plans to resurrect the fabled MG marque in a tricontinental demonstration of how truly global the automotive industry has become.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, July 11 - Can the mystique of a British sports car be recreated by a Chinese company in America's heartland?

articles.headline: Yeah, They Torture Jeans. But Its All for the Sake of Fashion.
articles.snippet: Giovanni Petrin remembers well his first efforts at beating up jeans.     Italian industrialists had visited Japan years ago to observe how the Japanese washed denim garments with small stones. ''So we took white stones from riverbeds here in the ...
articles.abstract: Giovanni Petrin remembers well his first efforts at beating up jeans.     Italian industrialists had visited Japan years ago to observe how the Japanese washed denim garments with small stones. ''So we took white stones from riverbeds here in the Veneto,'' said Mr. Petrin, referring to the northern Italian region where his jeans factory is situated. ''It destroyed the washing machines, and the jeans.''
articles.lead_paragraph: VEDELAGO, Italy - Giovanni Petrin remembers well his first efforts at beating up jeans.

articles.headline: Wave of Violence in Baghdad Puts 3-Day Death Toll Past 100
articles.snippet: More than 50 people were killed in Baghdad on Tuesday in violence that included a double suicide bombing near busy entrances to the fortified Green Zone, scattered shootings, mortar attacks, a series of car bombs and the ambush of a bus with Shiit...
articles.abstract: More than 50 people were killed in Baghdad on Tuesday in violence that included a double suicide bombing near busy entrances to the fortified Green Zone, scattered shootings, mortar attacks, a series of car bombs and the ambush of a bus with Shiite mourners returning from a burial.      Tuesday's killings, many of them apparently carried out with sectarian vengeance, raised the three-day death toll in the capital alone to well over 100, magnified the daunting challenges facing the new government and deepened a sense of dread among Iraqis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 11 - More than 50 people were killed in Baghdad on Tuesday in violence that included a double suicide bombing near busy entrances to the fortified Green Zone, scattered shootings, mortar attacks, a series of car bombs and the ambush of a bus with Shiite mourners returning from a burial.

articles.headline: U.S. Finance Pulls Biotech Across Seas
articles.snippet: When the Scottish economic development agency injected about $9 million into the biotechnology company Cyclacel last October, the country's enterprise minister explained that ''there could not be a more important company for Scotland's future.''  ...
articles.abstract: When the Scottish economic development agency injected about $9 million into the biotechnology company Cyclacel last October, the country's enterprise minister explained that ''there could not be a more important company for Scotland's future.''      But only two months later, this flag-bearer for Scottish biotechnology said it would move its headquarters to Short Hills, N.J., and merge with a publicly traded American company.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Scottish economic development agency injected about $9 million into the biotechnology company Cyclacel last October, the country's enterprise minister explained that "there could not be a more important company for Scotland's future."

articles.headline: Olympics Imperil Historic Beijing Neighborhood
articles.snippet: A short walk from Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People, a historic neighborhood named Qianmen is an eerie picture of destruction. Ancient homes lie in rubble. Scavengers squat in alleyways and wait to ransack vacated buildings.      T...
articles.abstract: A short walk from Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People, a historic neighborhood named Qianmen is an eerie picture of destruction. Ancient homes lie in rubble. Scavengers squat in alleyways and wait to ransack vacated buildings.      The reason for the devastation is the 2008 Olympic Games, which have turned much of the city into a noisy, disjointed construction zone. New subway lines and new roads are under construction, even an entire new downtown. On the city's northern rim, at least 25,000 laborers are building the Olympic stadiums and village.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING - A short walk from Tiananmen Square and the Great Hall of the People, a historic neighborhood named Qianmen is an eerie picture of destruction. Ancient homes lie in rubble. Scavengers squat in alleyways and wait to ransack vacated buildings.

articles.headline: Series of Bombs Explode on 7 Trains in India, Killing Scores
articles.snippet: A string of powerful bombs ripped through a vital spine of Mumbai's commuter train system during the evening rush hour on Tuesday, killing nearly 200 people, bringing India's financial capital to a standstill and resurrecting memories of bloodbath...
articles.abstract: A string of powerful bombs ripped through a vital spine of Mumbai's commuter train system during the evening rush hour on Tuesday, killing nearly 200 people, bringing India's financial capital to a standstill and resurrecting memories of bloodbaths past.     The Indian police placed the death toll at 190, with the number of wounded exceeding 600, according to the Press Trust of India. The casualties are likely to climb, for if nothing else, it was clear even in the chaotic aftermath of the blasts that the attacks were as cold-blooded as they were well-coordinated, intended to inflict maximum carnage.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India, July 11 - A string of powerful bombs ripped through a vital spine of Mumbai's commuter train system during the evening rush hour on Tuesday, killing nearly 200 people, bringing India's financial capital to a standstill and resurrecting memories of bloodbaths past.
articles.byline: By Saritha Rai and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Some in U.S. Tighten Security
articles.snippet: New York, Los Angeles and Atlanta added police officers at transit hubs, but Washington relied on public-safety announcements. Page A6.
articles.abstract: New York, Los Angeles and Atlanta added police officers at transit hubs, but Washington relied on public-safety announcements. Page A6.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York, Los Angeles and Atlanta added police officers at transit hubs, but Washington relied on public-safety announcements. Page A6.

articles.headline: Russians and U.S. Push Hard on Trade
articles.snippet: Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said on Tuesday.      Russia is by far the world's largest economy still outside the W.T.O.,...
articles.abstract: Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said on Tuesday.      Russia is by far the world's largest economy still outside the W.T.O., a 149-nation group that sets the ground rules for global trade and investment. The United States has withheld its approval for letting the Russians into the organization, even after other countries signed off on membership.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, July 11 - Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Moscow into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: Come One, Come All, Join the Terror Target List
articles.snippet: It reads like a tally of terrorist targets that a child might have written: Old MacDonald's Petting Zoo, the Amish Country Popcorn factory, the Mule Day Parade, the Sweetwater Flea Market and an unspecified ''Beach at End of a Street.''     But th...
articles.abstract: It reads like a tally of terrorist targets that a child might have written: Old MacDonald's Petting Zoo, the Amish Country Popcorn factory, the Mule Day Parade, the Sweetwater Flea Market and an unspecified ''Beach at End of a Street.''     But the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security, in a report released Tuesday, found that the list was not child's play: all these ''unusual or out-of-place'' sites ''whose criticality is not readily apparent'' are inexplicably included in the federal antiterrorism database.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11 - It reads like a tally of terrorist targets that a child might have written: Old MacDonald's Petting Zoo, the Amish Country Popcorn factory, the Mule Day Parade, the Sweetwater Flea Market and an unspecified "Beach at End of a Street."
